Context:
The Event Management program at George Brown College offers a capstone event and a mandatory 14-week work-integrated learning placement. Students have the opportunity to switch to any of the hospitality and tourism management diploma programs by their second year if their area of interest changes. The common first-year model makes students eligible to graduate with a one-year certificate in Hospitality Services (H101) should they not be able to complete their final year of study.

The program provides a final capstone event and mandatory work placement, with employers and industry partners identified for potential work experience opportunities. Students are encouraged to pursue self-directed event management industry work experience opportunities. In addition to formal on-the-job work experience, George Brown College endeavors to provide learning opportunities with real-world challenges and customers.

Career options for graduates include roles such as event planner, conference planner, meeting planner, catering manager, incentive travel manager, festival planner, social event planner, event fundraiser, and volunteer coordinator.

Qualified graduates of the Event Planning program may be eligible to enter the Honours Bachelor of Business Administration (Hospitality) degree program at George Brown College as an advanced standing student in September or January, or start in the spring bridging semester from May to August, continuing into the degree program in September. This educational path requires a minimum grade point average of 2.7 to qualify.

The first-semester required courses include HOST 1085: Principles of Hospitality and Tourism Management, HOST 1171: Global Accommodation Industry, HOST 1172: Introduction to Wines and Beverages, HOST 1070: Introduction to Catering, and HOST 1146: Leading.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Event Planning Program H141 | George Brown College2024.txt

Course outlines and Program Learning Outcomes for the graduate are also mentioned in the text. The learning outcomes include planning and designing events, selecting catering services, developing marketing plans, and coordinating/supervising staff.

Context:
The text provides information on various roles and responsibilities of an events coordinator, along with the tuition fees and additional costs for a program at the college starting in Fall 2023 and Fall 2024. Here's the extracted information:

Roles and Responsibilities of an Events Coordinator:
1. Meet the needs of the organization or client.
2. Supervise staff, contractors, and volunteers.
3. Employ best practices for financial management.
4. Manage business transactions of event projects.
5. Develop risk mitigation strategies.
6. Maintain ethical practices and professionalism.
7. Apply intercultural awareness and inclusion strategies.
8. Use industry-standard technology platforms.
9. Secure sponsorships, funds or grants.
10. Engage in ongoing learning.
11. Identify new career opportunities.
12. Communicate information persuasively and accurately.

Tuition Fees for Fall 2023:
Domestic Students: $4,980.00 (estimated total of tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees for the first two semesters)
International Students: $19,017.00 (estimated total of tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees for the first two semesters)

Additional Costs:
Textbooks, manuals etc.: $575 (subject to change)
Uniform: Included in material fees - black pants, grey Oxford shirt, and a bib apron.

Financial Assistance:
The program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet OSAP eligibility criteria.

Disclaimer: The information contained in this website is subject to change without notice.

Context:
The George Brown College has varying admission requirements for applicants based on their academic achievements and other criteria. Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma (OSSD) or its equivalent, including a Grade 12 English credit (C or U). Mature students may apply through taking the Admissions Assessment for English or upgrading to achieve the required English credit. The College grants course exemptions based on college or university credits and has specific admission requirements for international students. Students should be aware of potential allergens in practical labs and George Brown's sensitivity to religious observances regarding food.

Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should use the George Brown College Online Application System. For inquiries related to domestic admissions, contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit their webpage. Financial inquiries can be directed to the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or their Financial Aid webpage.

The College has a limited number of seats available for applicants through completion of the Hospitality Services (Pre-Hospitality) program (H101), but admission is not guaranteed. George Brown College is committed to ensuring that applicants will succeed in their chosen program and meeting minimum requirements does not guarantee admission. Students may be required to have higher grades than stated for admission.

Course exemptions are granted based on college or university credits, and more information can be found in the Transfer Guide. International students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements. The College has a Health Policy regarding allergens and religious observances related to food.

Contact information:
Domestic Students: admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions web page.
Financial Inquiries: FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid web page.
